step1_initial_points.title: Market Landscape and Solution Discovery
step1_initial_points.description: The buyer is struggling to navigate the complex and evolving AI market. They need to identify innovative, mature, and relevant tools that can genuinely enhance efficiency, decision-making, and service delivery in a government context.

step1_initial_points.title: Ensuring Data Security and Governance
step1_initial_points.description: A primary concern is safeguarding sensitive government data when using AI tools. The buyer must ensure any solution complies with strict government ICT, security, cyber, and privacy policies, and wants clarity on how vendors protect this information.

step1_initial_points.title: Integration with Existing Systems
step1_initial_points.description: The buyer needs assurance that new AI solutions can be successfully integrated into their existing government systems. They are assessing the adaptability and scalability of vendor solutions to avoid creating data silos or requiring costly overhauls.

step1_initial_points.title: Budget Planning & Cost Uncertainty
step1_initial_points.description: The buyer lacks clear cost models for AI solutions, making future procurement planning and budget allocation difficult. They need indicative pricing to understand the total cost of ownership and build a business case for investment.

step1_initial_points.title: Validating Performance in Government
step1_initial_points.description: The buyer is risk-averse and needs evidence that proposed AI tools are reliable with a proven performance history in a similar public sector context. They seek successful deployment examples and pilots to validate vendor claims and de-risk adoption.

step1_initial_points.title: Internal Resource and Skill Gaps
step1_initial_points.description: The buyer is concerned about the internal impact of AI adoption. They need to understand the specific resources, infrastructure changes, and staff training required for a successful deployment and the ongoing operation of new AI tools.

step1_initial_points.title: Future-Proofing and Scalability
step1_initial_points.description: The buyer wants to avoid investing in dead-end technology. They need to understand a solution's scalability, adaptability, and planned future enhancements to ensure it remains viable and effective for long-term government operations.

step1_initial_points.title: Adherence to Public Sector Regulations
step1_initial_points.description: Any AI solution must strictly comply with specific public sector regulations like the SA Information Privacy Principles (IPPs). This legal and policy adherence is a non-negotiable requirement for any tool handling government information.

step2_filtered_points.title: Ensuring Data Security and Governance
step2_filtered_points.description: A primary concern is safeguarding sensitive government data when using AI tools. The buyer must ensure any solution complies with strict government ICT, security, cyber, and privacy policies, and wants clarity on how vendors protect this information.

step2_filtered_points.title: Adherence to Public Sector Regulations
step2_filtered_points.description: Any AI solution must strictly comply with specific public sector regulations like the SA Information Privacy Principles (IPPs). This legal and policy adherence is a non-negotiable requirement for any tool handling government information.

step2_filtered_points.title: Integration with Existing Systems
step2_filtered_points.description: The buyer needs assurance that new AI solutions can be successfully integrated into their existing government systems. They are assessing the adaptability and scalability of vendor solutions to avoid creating data silos or requiring costly overhauls.

step2_filtered_points.title: Validating Performance in Government
step2_filtered_points.description: The buyer is risk-averse and needs evidence that proposed AI tools are reliable with a proven performance history in a similar public sector context. They seek successful deployment examples and pilots to validate vendor claims and de-risk adoption.

step2_filtered_points.title: Internal Resource and Skill Gaps
step2_filtered_points.description: The buyer is concerned about the internal impact of AI adoption. They need to understand the specific resources, infrastructure changes, and staff training required for a successful deployment and the ongoing operation of new AI tools.

step2_filtered_points.title: Future-Proofing and Scalability
step2_filtered_points.description: The buyer wants to avoid investing in dead-end technology. They need to understand a solution's scalability, adaptability, and planned future enhancements to ensure it remains viable and effective for long-term government operations.

step3_refined_points.title: Ensuring Security and Regulatory Compliance
step3_refined_points.description: A primary, non-negotiable concern is safeguarding sensitive government data. Any AI solution must comply with strict ICT, security, and privacy policies, as well as specific legal frameworks like the SA Information Privacy Principles (IPPs), to be considered for adoption.

step3_refined_points.title: Validating Performance in a Public Sector Context
step3_refined_points.description: The buyer is risk-averse and requires concrete evidence that proposed AI tools are reliable with a proven performance history in a similar public sector environment. They seek successful deployment examples and pilots to validate vendor claims and de-risk technology adoption.

step3_refined_points.title: Technical Integration & Future Viability
step3_refined_points.description: The buyer needs assurance that a solution will integrate seamlessly with existing systems to avoid data silos and costly overhauls. They are also assessing scalability and future roadmaps to ensure the technology is a sustainable, long-term investment rather than a dead-end.

step3_refined_points.title: Addressing Internal Resource and Skill Gaps
step3_refined_points.description: The buyer is concerned about the internal capacity to implement and manage AI. They must understand the specific staff skills, training, infrastructure changes, and other resources required for successful deployment and the ongoing operation of new AI tools across government.

merge_decisions.merged: Validating Performance in a Public Sector Context
Addressing Internal Resource and Skill Gaps

pain_points_final.title: Ensuring Security and Regulatory Compliance
pain_points_final.description: A primary, non-negotiable concern is safeguarding sensitive government data. Any AI solution must comply with strict ICT, security, and privacy policies, as well as specific legal frameworks like the SA Information Privacy Principles (IPPs), to be considered for adoption.
